textBeforeTable: There are nine wetlands in Chile recognized as important under the the Convention on Wetlands (Ramsar Convention):   73,791 8 UNESCO-MAB Biosphere Reserves   1,592 9 Wetlands of International importance (Ramsar Sites)     5 Nationally recognized protected areas greater than 10,000 km2     20 Nationally recognized protected areas greater than 1,000 km2         Note that some protected areas include both terrestrial area and marine area   770 9     Marine and Littoral Protected Area 18.8% 142,345 102     Terrestrial (% of Chile's Terrestrial Territorial Area) 14.0% 143,114 106 Total Area of nationally recognized protected areas (% of Chile's Territorial Area)   Area km2 # of Areas    Protected area highlights for Chile (includes Easter Island) (January 31, 2008): This content is not assigned to a topic Topics: WDPA Juan Pablo ArceTopic Editor: Source:
textAfterTable: Other internationally recognized areas of significance are eight UNESCO-MAB Biosphere Reserves: Cabo de Hornos Biosphere Reserve - (49,000 km2, 3,000 marine) Laguna San Rafael Biosphere Reserve -(17,420 km2) Parque Nacional Fray Jorge Biosphere Reserve - (735 km2) Parque Nacional Juan Fernández Biosphere Reserve - (100 km2) Parque Nacional Torres del Paine Biosphere Reserve - (1,844 km2) Reserva de la Biósfera Araucarias Biosphere Reserve - (938 km2) Reserva de la Biósfera La Campana-Peñuelas Biosphere Reserve - (171 km2) Reserva Nacional Lauca Biosphere Reserve - (3,583 km2) The latest World Database on Protected Areas reports 212 nationally recognized protected areas in Chile (106 more than the summary above): Site Name IUCN Designation Marine or Terrestrial Total Area (hectares) Total Marine Area (hectares) Alacalufes (National Reserve) IV Terrestrial 2,313,875   Alberto de Agostini (National Park) II Terrestrial 1,460,000   Alerce Andino (National Park) II Terrestrial 39,255   Alerce Costero III Terrestrial 2,308   Alicahue - Terrestrial
